thread.title: Stoke and Copeland by-election results LIVE: Labour battles Ukip and Tories to keep seats after Storm Doris chaos
thread.title_full: Stoke and Copeland by-election results LIVE: Labour battles Ukip and Tories to keep seats after Storm Doris chaos - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: Stoke and Copeland by-election results LIVE: Labour battles Ukip and Tories to keep seats after Storm Doris chaos
text:
Stoke and Copeland by-election results LIVE: Labour battles Ukip and Tories to keep seats after Storm Doris chaos Follow live updates all night from the count in Stoke-on-Trent Central, as Labour bids to hold off Ukip's Paul Nuttall, and Copeland in Cumbria   Share By Dan Bloom Updated 21:12, 23 FEB 2017 News Ukip leader Paul Nuttall today out in Stoke, (Photo: Getty)   Share Storm Doris is slowly sweeping away - but tonight the clouds gather in the political world for two crunch by-elections.
Labour has been battling to stop Ukip leader Paul Nuttall wiping out its 5,000 majority in Stoke-on-Trent Central.
And the party is trying to stop the Tories claiming its 2,500-vote hold in the Lake District seat of Copeland.
It's been nail-biting for Labour as both areas backed Brexit and, some argue, have been isolated from the people who make decisions in Westminster. Today voters battled their way to windswept polling stations amid fears of low turnout. 
Tonight political reporter Dan Bloom is at the count in Stoke while Deputy Political Editor Ben Glaze makes the journey to Copeland.
Follow their updates all night with results, analysis and reaction below. For candidates, odds and more, read our guide to Copeland here and our guide to Stoke here. 
Key Events Compare to the results in 2015 20:54 What time is the result? 20:51 21:12 Dan Bloom Claim and counter-claim... will turnout be 30%? Now’s the time of the night for fevered speculation as the polls enter their final hour.
One Labour source claims turnout in Stoke is looking to be around 30%, which they actually describe as OK - considering Stoke Central had the lowest turnout in the country in 2015.
An earlier source said they’d be surprised if it rose above 28%.
The lower the turnout, the fewer votes one party needs to cause an upset.
Meanwhile, a source claims confidently that Ukip could be knocked into third place in Stoke behind the Tories. But a Ukip source insists they’d be very surprised if that happens.
20:54 KEY EVENT Compare to the results in 2015 Labour won both seats at the 2015 general election - it’s held Stoke since the 1980s and Copeland since the 1950s.
In Stoke Ukip won second place around 5,000 votes behind - and the Tories were in third, 33 votes behind them.
Copeland is a simpler two-way fight with Labour winning a 2,500 majority over the Conservatives.
20:51 KEY EVENT What time is the result? These things are not an exact science, but it’ll be in the wee hours.
Stoke has told us to expect a result between 3am and 4am, but it could be as early as 1am if there’s a clear result and low turnout.
Copeland has given us a rough guide time of 3am.
20:45 Dan Bloom Hundreds of activists flood Stoke amid fears for turnout amid Storm Doris Hundreds of activists battled Storm Doris today for a last-minute push for votes in the race to win Stoke-on-Trent Central - a Labour seat since 1950.
Labour and Ukip each had more than 200 people knocking on doors and manning polling stations despite rain and wind battering the Potteries.
But Ukip leader Paul Nuttall, who was bidding to overturn Labour’s 5,179 majority, admitted: “It’s obviously going to affect the turnout.”
The tweed-clad candidate was forced to change his clothes after one downpour.
He added: “It could go any way.”
Tory candidate Jack Brereton joined his party chairman Patrick McLoughlin in Stoke to meet voters hours before polls closed:
(Photo: PA) Labour’s candidate Gareth Snell joined MPs and activists for canvassing while other Labour activists called voters from a London phone bank.
Campaign organiser and MP Jack Dromey claimed more than 500 Labour activists were involved on polling day.
He said before the result: “I think the turnout is bound to be low because of the extreme weather. This is one of the worst storms of the last 50 years.
“I think if we win tonight Ukip are likely to end up in crisis because they would have thrown everything at their one objective and failed.
“We’re not taking anything for granted because it remains tough and tight, but we’re cautiously optimistic.”
Storm Doris saw a woman in her 60s hospitalised for a “serious head injury” after being hit by a carport roof in Hartshill, Stoke.

A Ukip spokesman also witnessed a tree crush a children’s play area:
(Photo: PA)   Share More On Storm Doris Politics Labour Party UKIP Jeremy Corbyn
